term.name: SSH Key
term.definition: An encoded string used to authenticate requests or connections by comparing a public and private version of the string

term.name: Test Driven Development (TDD)
term.definition: A software development process that relies on writing tests before writing any code

term.name: TypeScript
term.definition: An open-source programming language built to add typing to JavaScript

term.name: User Interface (UI)
term.definition: The design users are provided to interact with a product or application

term.name: Go
term.definition: A typed programming language with a gopher as its mascot

term.name: JSON Web Tokens (JWT)
term.definition: A way for us to store JSON data in a "token" format, meaning it will have a tamper evident check involved

term.name: LAMBDA
term.definition: An anonymous function definition that is not bound to an identifier

term.name: Base64
term.definition: An encoding used to embed small images or icons directly into a page using `data-uri:`

term.name: Library
term.definition: A collection of precompiled routines that a program can use, commonly for a specific task or tasks

term.name: Wrapper
term.definition: Code encompassed around other code to manage its children

term.name: Module Loader
term.definition: A way to load or package items for easy importing / exporting

term.name: Promise
term.definition: A spec for interacting and working with Asynchronous code. A Promise has three states to it: pending, resolved, failed.

term.name: Debug
term.definition: An attempt to resolve issues related to problems found in code or an application

term.name: Accumulator Pattern
term.definition: A code pattern referring to the accumulation of a value or values. Commonly used to restructure or modify data into a usable format.

term.name: Continuous Integration (CI)
term.definition: The practice of merging all developer working copies to a shared mainline several times a day

term.name: Sprint
term.definition: A part of the SCRUM technique, a set period of time during which specific work has to be completed and made ready for review

term.name: Spaghetti Code
term.definition: Code that is not structured in a functional way. For example, a line or two of code, followed by another line or two of unrelated code.

term.name: Method
term.definition: Similar to a Function, but belongs to an Object or Class instead

term.name: Algorithm
term.definition: A well-defined procedure that allows a computer to solve a problem

term.name: Environment Variable
term.definition: A value that impacts the processes and behavior of running in specific environments

term.name: Continuous Delivery (CD)
term.definition: A software engineering approach in which teams produce software in short cycles, ensuring that the software can be reliably released at any time

term.name: Edge Case
term.definition: A problem or situation that occurs only at an extreme (maximum or minimum) operating parameter

term.name: Instance
term.definition: A specific realization of any Object, with its own set of properties or methods

term.name: Create Read Update Delete (CRUD)
term.definition: A set of four common actions performed on data

term.name: Runtime Error
term.definition: An error that occurred while we were running our application

term.name: null
term.definition: A primitive data type to declare a value as "empty"

term.name: undefined
term.definition: A data type where the value has not been defined. This is the default when declaring a variable but giving it no value.

term.name: Cookie
term.definition: A small piece of data sent with HTTP requests, stored on the user's computer by the web browser

term.name: Pure Function
term.definition: A pure function is a function which given the same input, will always return the same output. Produces no side effects.

term.name: noop
term.definition: noop means "no operation", a function that does nothing on purpose. A noop can be used to hold place for an optional callback to be overridden.

term.name: Code Smell
term.definition: Any symptom in the source code of a program that possibly indicates a deeper problem. Common examples are complex functions, duplicate code, long lines of code, etc.

term.name: Anti-pattern
term.definition: A pattern (of code or design) considered to be bad practice

term.name: Velocity
term.definition: A metric for work done in agile software development

term.name: Coercion
term.definition: The act of explicitly or implicitly converting the data type to check for a match. Commonly enacted with use of `==` or `===`.

term.name: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)
term.definition: A browser implemented security feature to allow or deny making requests from one domain to another.

term.name: Event Loop
term.definition: Closely tied to the Call Stack, the Event Loop will help handle our code being called by preventing it from "blocking" while it's waiting to complete.

term.name: Immutable
term.definition: A value that is not allowed or meant to be changed

term.name: Integer
term.definition: A data type of a number

term.name: String
term.definition: A data type with a textual value

term.name: Session Hijacking
term.definition: A hacking technique used to steal a users session

term.name: Repository
term.definition: A storage place for versions of tracked files in source control

term.name: Shell
term.definition: A command line tool frequently included with Unix systems

term.name: Middleware
term.definition: Computer software that provides services to software applications beyond those available from the operating system. It can be described as "software glue".

term.name: Pull Request (PR)
term.definition: A request to merge changes from another branch or repository on Github

term.name: Rebase
term.definition: The act of rewriting the base of your branch from one commit to another

term.name: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS)
term.definition: The language used to give an HTML page its visual style

term.name: Assembly
term.definition: A low-level programming language for a computer, or other programmable device

term.name: Compile
term.definition: The translation of source code into machine code

term.name: Currying
term.definition: Breaking down a function that takes multiple arguments into a series of functions that take part of the arguments

term.name: Factory Pattern
term.definition: In class-based programming, this pattern creates new objects of a specific Class

term.name: NoSQL
term.definition: A database providing data in means other than the tabular relations used in relational databases

term.name: Parse
term.definition: To divide language into small components that can be analyzed and interpreted

term.name: Responsive Design
term.definition: An approach to web page creation that makes use of flexible layouts, flexible images and cascading style sheet media queries

term.name: Session
term.definition: A way to track subsequent interactions between a client and server, even through stateless protocols such as HTTP

term.name: Hotfix
term.definition: A fix for a bug that is quickly patched and pushed to production, instead of waiting for the next release. Usually occurs when a bug has slipped through QA and made it to production.

term.name: Encode / Decode
term.definition: A way to convert data to and from of a specific format. Encoding / Decoding is not a secure way of converting or storing data.

term.name: Anonymous Function
term.definition: A function without a name. Usually passed as a callback or one-time use.

term.name: Array
term.definition: A data type for storing items in a "list", "collection", etc. Arrays are zero-index based and preserve their order unlike Objects.

term.name: Asynchronous / Synchronous
term.definition: A way to run our code in order (synchronously) or to run at the same time and wait for a response (async).

term.name: Call Stack
term.definition: A mechanism to keep the place of the current running function in our code. The Call Stack will work it's way in and out of functions in the order we called them.

term.name: Closure
term.definition: An inner function that has access to an outer functions scope. Commonly used with Anonymous Functions being passed into a Higher-order Function.

term.name: Component
term.definition: A reusable, custom built element, usually including HTML / CSS and JavaScript.

term.name: Constructor
term.definition: A function used with the `new` keyword to create a new Instance. Constructors are commonly named with capital first letters.

term.name: Control Flow
term.definition: The various ways we control our script based on our needs. Control Flow includes keywords such as `if / else`.

term.name: Destructuring
term.definition: A feature of ES6 allowing us to pull out multiple variables from an Object or Array.

term.name: Event Bubbling
term.definition: A feature of the DOM triggered when an Event starts at the target (source of the event) and makes it way up the chain until it reaches the `document`.

term.name: Expression
term.definition: The part of the code that resolves to a value. For example, `3 + 4` ends with `7` while `var total = 3 + 4` ends with the value being assigned to variable.

term.name: Function
term.definition: A set of statements to be performed together as a task. Functions can be defined and called at different times, often to be called more than once.

term.name: Hoisting
term.definition: A behavior in JavaScript that results in variables and functions being declared first. This could effect the values of variables if you are not aware.

term.name: Inheritance
term.definition: A way for us to extend on existing code, often to add new functionality or override existing functionality. In JavaScript, Inheritance is generally referring to the `prototype`.

term.name: JavaScript Object Notation (JSON)
term.definition: A data format commonly used on the web to exchange data between servers or store in a standardized format.

term.name: Linter
term.definition: A code quality tool often built into build tools or code editors

term.name: Native Methods
term.definition: Methods or functionality built-in to JavaScript via the prototype

term.name: Object
term.definition: A data type that stores the properties in a "key / value" format. The values can be anything that is assigned to a normal variable.

term.name: Operator
term.definition: Specific character(s) to perform an operation. For example: arithmetic (`+ - * /`), comparisons (`< >= ==`), logical (`&& ||`), etc.

term.name: Prototype
term.definition: The base Object an item inherits from. Holds all the built-in functionality JavaScript offers us, as well as the ability to extend it to our liking.

term.name: Scope
term.definition: The area in which we have access to other defined variables. A few types of scope are global, local, or lexical.

term.name: Single-page Application (SPA)
term.definition: An application that serves from a single page (often `index.html`) and may include client-side routing.

term.name: Spread Operator
term.definition: A feature of ES6, a way to expand an Arrays values or Objects properties. Commonly used when writing Immutable code.

term.name: this
term.definition: A reference to the current context in a function or scope

term.name: Transpile
term.definition: Converting code from one format or language to another, such as ES6 to ES5 or Typescript to JavaScript.

term.name: Number
term.definition: A data type of numerical value

term.name: Symbol
term.definition: A primitive data type that creates a unique value for use as an identifier on Object properties

term.name: Boolean
term.definition: A primary data type of binary value. For example: `true || false`, `yes || no`, `0 || 1`.

term.name: Primitive / Reference Types
term.definition: The two types of ways to define a variable, referring to the way it is stored in memory. A Primitive Type is a value that is not an Object and has no methods, such as `string, number, boolean, null, undefined, symbol`. A Reference Type is pointing to something defined elsewhere, such as another variable or Primitive Type.

term.name: Pseudo Code
term.definition: A high-level description of what steps a program is completing

term.name: Accessibility
term.definition: The availability of an application or site with the use of screen-readers

term.name: Transaction
term.definition: A sequence of information exchange that is treated as a unit (all or none) for the purposes of satisfying a request and for ensuring integrity

term.name: Auth Strategy
term.definition: The implementation of our Authentication methods, such as OAuth or local (meaning standard username and password)

term.name: DOM Traversal
term.definition: To move your way through the DOM via child and parent nodes

term.name: DOM Node
term.definition: A JavaScript reference to an element on the page that allows us to manipulate the contents, properties, etc.

term.name: Router
term.definition: Our code handling the pointers from a URL to a specific page to serve up. Routing can be handled server-side or client-side.

term.name: Static Assets
term.definition: Files in our application that are served directly and do not need any additional processing such as server-side code or requesting information from a database.

term.name: Event Delegation
term.definition: A way to capture events on descendant elements by listening to one of its parents or ancestors

term.name: Commit
term.definition: A saved point in source control history

term.name: Happy Path
term.definition: A default scenario featuring no exceptional or error conditions, comprising the sequence of activities executed if everything goes as expected

term.name: Build
term.definition: A deployable version of an application or code, commonly versioned for release tracking

term.name: PostgreSQL (PSQL)
term.definition: An open source relational database management system based on traditional SQL, also referred to as `pg`

term.name: Stage / Unstage
term.definition: To add or remove files to the next Git commit

term.name: Version Control / Source Control
term.definition: A file versioning platform to track changes and revisions to documents over time

term.name: Semantic Versioning (SemVer)
term.definition: A versioning spec that uses the format `major.minor.patch` (e.g. `1.3.1`)

term.name: Stack Overflow
term.definition: A question and answer site for professional and enthusiast programmers named after a common programming error

term.name: Markdown
term.definition: A textual format that is converted to HTML when rendered

term.name: Invoke
term.definition: To call a function or method

term.name: CSS Selector
term.definition: The CSS path to select a specific element or elements on a page

term.name: Map-Filter-Reduce
term.definition: A common set of methods to use when manipulating or modifying data, possibly in an Immutable manner.

term.name: Client
term.definition: Any computer that is receiving something from a server. Commonly referring to the Browser on a users computer.

term.name: Margin
term.definition: The space outside of an elements bounding box

term.name: Padding
term.definition: The space between the inside of an elements bounding box and its content

term.name: Variable
term.definition: A value saved to a named item that can change over time

term.name: Constant
term.definition: A value that is set but cannot be changed later on

term.name: Statement
term.definition: A group of syntax to form one or more lines of code

term.name: Import / Export
term.definition: The build in module system for ES6

term.name: Parameter
term.definition: The definition of options a function can take when being called

term.name: Argument
term.definition: The values passed to a function when it is being called

term.name: Bash
term.definition: A.k.a. born-again shell, the default terminal for Mac OS X. May also be referred to as Terminal, Shell, CLI.

term.name: Firebase
term.definition: A cloud platform for hosting, data storage, and more, owned by Google.

term.name: Stringify
term.definition: To convert data to a String version while keeping its data type intact.

term.name: Terminal
term.definition: A core application built to interpret commands via an interface

term.name: Static Typed
term.definition: A language in which type checking is done at compile-time

term.name: Gulp
term.definition: A CLI tool to help with the front end build process. The logo is a cup.

term.name: Universally Unique Identifier (UUID)
term.definition: Unlike most other numbering schemes, this is for practical purposes unique, without depending for their uniqueness on a central registration authority or coordination between the parties generating them

term.name: Grunt
term.definition: A CLI tool to help with the front end build process. The logo is a bull.

term.name: JIRA
term.definition: A project management platform built by Atlassian targeting Enterprise customers

term.name: Pivotal Tracker
term.definition: A project management platform built by Pivotal

term.name: Trello
term.definition: A free Kanban platform made for simplicity, now owned by Atlassian

term.name: Git
term.definition: A source control manager with a three letter name

term.name: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
term.definition: A collection of infrastructure services started by one of the largest e-commerce companies in the world

term.name: Software as a Service (SaaS)
term.definition: A business who sells a subscription to proprietary software

term.name: Platform as a Service (PaaS)
term.definition: A business selling cloud computing as a subscription

term.name: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)
term.definition: A business selling virtualized computing resources on a subscription

term.name: Font Icons
term.definition: A way to include icons into the page through typography

term.name: Grid
term.definition: A CSS spec allowing both columns and rows to be used for layout

term.name: Flexbox
term.definition: A CSS spec providing a more efficient way to lay out, align and distribute space among items in a container, even when their size is unknown and/or dynamic

term.name: jQuery
term.definition: A JavaScript library to make cross-browser DOM manipulation easier to use with CSS Selectors

term.name: querySelector / querySelectorAll
term.definition: Native JavaScript method to grab an element on the page using CSS Selectors

term.name: Document
term.definition: A JavaScript object containing the DOM Tree and supporting methods.

term.name: D3.js
term.definition: A JavaScript library for visualizing data with HTML, SVG, and CSS.

term.name: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG)
term.definition: An XML-based markup language for describing two dimensional based vector graphics.

term.name: Canvas
term.definition: An HTML element used to draw graphics, on the fly, via scripting (usually JavaScript)

term.name: Node Package Manager (npm)
term.definition: A package manager for JavaScript, also the world's largest software registry

term.name: Float
term.definition: A CSS property specifying an element is removed from the normal flow of the web page, placing it along the left or right side of its container, allowing text and inline elements to wrap around it.

term.name: await
term.definition: A JavaScript expression used with async to pause execution until a Promise has a resolution

term.name: Higher-Order Function (HOF)
term.definition: A function that takes functions as arguments, or returns a function as its result

term.name: Higher-Order Component (HOC)
term.definition: A function that takes a component and returns a new component

term.name: DOM Tree
term.definition: The hierarchy of the elements on the page, converted into JavaScript as nodes.

term.name: Document Object Model (DOM)
term.definition: A representation of an HTML Document converted into a programmable interface

term.name: Box Model
term.definition: A box that wraps around every HTML element consisting of a margin, border, padding, and the actual content

term.name: Heroku
term.definition: A platform as a service (PaaS) owned by Salesforce that enables developers to build, run, and operate applications entirely in the cloud

term.name: Obfuscate
term.definition: The deliberate act of creating source or machine code that is difficult for humans to understand

term.name: Hyper-Text Transfer Protocol (HTTP)
term.definition: An application protocol for distributed, collaborative, and hypermedia information systems which is also the foundation of data communication for the World Wide Web

term.name: World Wide Web (www)
term.definition: An information space where documents and other web resources are identified by URLs, interlinked by hypertext links, and can be accessed via the Internet

term.name: Uniform Resource Locator (URL)
term.definition: A reference to a web resource that specifies its location on a computer network and a mechanism for retrieving it

term.name: Uniform Resource Identifier (URI)
term.definition: A string of characters used to identify a resource, such as a URL

term.name: Unit Tests
term.definition: A software testing method by which individual units of source code

term.name: Dependency Injection (DI)
term.definition: A technique whereby one object supplies the dependencies of another object

term.name: Abstraction
term.definition: One of three central principles in OOP, a programmer hides all but the relevant data about an object in order to reduce complexity and increase efficiency

term.name: Acceptence Tests
term.definition: A test to evaluate the system's compliance with the business requirements and assess whether it is acceptable for delivery

term.name: Fork
term.definition: A hosted copy of a Git repository to allow open source contributions or derivative works on Github

term.name: Asynchronous JavaScript and XML (AJAX)
term.definition: A way of asynchronously making requests to servers from the client

term.name: Class
term.definition: In reference to OOP, this is used to create a definition for creating a new Object instance

term.name: KnexJS
term.definition: A query and schema builder for use in NodeJS

term.name: Artifacts
term.definition: One of many kinds of tangible by-products produced during the development of software to help describe the function, architecture, and design of software

term.name: Freeze
term.definition: A time in a project where changes are locked in preventing additional changes to allow for testing or analyzing

term.name: Kanban
term.definition: A lean approach aiming to manage work by balancing the demands with available capacity on a visible board

term.name: Regression
term.definition: A software bug that makes a feature stop functioning as intended after a certain event (e.g. daylight saving time)

term.name: Staging
term.definition: A deployment environment commonly used for debugging or QA work

term.name: Quality Assurance (QA)
term.definition: A means of monitoring the software engineering processes and methods used to ensure quality through automated or manual testing

term.name: Database (DB)
term.definition: A collection of information that is organized so it can be easily accessed, managed and updated

term.name: GraphQL
term.definition: A query language for your API, and a server-side runtime for executing queries by using a type system you define for your data

term.name: Ternary Operator
term.definition: An operator shorthand for an if / else statement

term.name: ReactJS
term.definition: A JavaScript library for building components, made by Facebook

term.name: Immediately-invoked Function Expression (IIFE)
term.definition: A wrapping function we invoke on definition to prevent new variables from being exposed to the current scope

term.name: Global Scope
term.definition: The scope tied to the whole application or script running

term.name: Local Scope
term.definition: Scope that cannot escape its current function

term.name: Lexical Scope
term.definition: Scope within the block level (inside curly braces)

term.name: Viewport
term.definition: The viewable area within a browser window

term.name: Webpack
term.definition: A CLI tool to bundle your assets together via loaders and plugins

term.name: Slack
term.definition: A chat tool for organizations, free up to 10,000 messages

term.name: VS Code
term.definition: A code editor built by Microsoft

term.name: Atom
term.definition: An open source code editor, built by Github

term.name: Virtual DOM
term.definition: A DOM stored and manipulated in memory for performance enhancements

term.name: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)
term.definition: The standard for creating a secure link between the web and browser

term.name: Secure Shell (SSH)
term.definition: A network protocol for connecting to networked services in a secure manner

term.name: Destructive
term.definition: An action performed that is non-recoverable such as deleting

term.name: Status Code
term.definition: The identification number attached to responses from HTTP requests

term.name: Wireframe
term.definition: A low-fidelity version of the layout of a website or application

term.name: Rollback
term.definition: Reset an item to its previous value(s)

term.name: Migrate
term.definition: Convert from one data structure to another, commonly with Database tables

term.name: Seed
term.definition: A default data set to start with

term.name: Remote
term.definition: A Git host somewhere other than our local machine

term.name: Join
term.definition: Connecting one table to another as relational data in a database

term.name: Branch
term.definition: A feature available in modern version control systems allowing the user to diverge the code base in parallel for later merging

term.name: Push / Pull
term.definition: Git commands used to send or receive the latest changes from a remote repository

term.name: Application Programming Interface (API)
term.definition: The interface in which we interact with a code base or application

term.name: Content Delivery Network (CDN)
term.definition: A server or servers dedicated to hosting static content, optimized for performance

term.name: Adaptive Design
term.definition: A design style that detects the device and other features, and then provides the appropriate feature and layout based on a predefined set of viewport sizes and other characteristics

term.name: Breakpoint
term.definition: A marker used when debugging code to tell the runtime to pause when it reaches a specific point

term.name: CSS Breakpoint
term.definition: A point at which the layout of a page changes to accompany a specific device size

term.name: Bubble Sort
term.definition: A simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly steps through the list to be sorted, compares each pair of adjacent items and swaps them if they are in the wrong order

term.name: Convention Over Configuration
term.definition: A software design paradigm attempting to decrease the number of decisions that a developer makes by offering a sensible default that can be overridden

term.name: Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF)
term.definition: An attack that forces an end user to execute unwanted actions on a web application in which they're currently authenticated, specifically state-changing requests

term.name: Cross-site Scripting (XSS)
term.definition: A security breach that takes advantage of dynamically generated web pages rendering JavaScript from a users input

term.name: Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY)
term.definition: A principle of software development aimed at reducing repetition of software patterns or duplicate code

term.name: Encapsulate
term.definition: One of the fundamentals of OOP, it refers to the bundling of data with the methods that operate on that data preventing direct access

term.name: Encrypt / Decrypt
term.definition: The process of encoding a message or information in such a way that only authorized parties can access it

term.name: Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD)
term.definition: A data modeling technique that graphically illustrates an information system's entities and the relationships between those entities

term.name: CSS Class
term.definition: A reusable style with a specific name such as `.highlighted`

term.name: File-transfer Protocol (FTP)
term.definition: A standard network protocol used for the transfer of computer files between a client and server

term.name: Framework
term.definition: An abstraction of generic functionality to provide faster development in software

term.name: Integration Tests
term.definition: Software testing in which individual software modules are combined and tested as a group

term.name: Interface
term.definition: A programming structure that allows the computer to enforce certain properties on an object

term.name: Interpolation
term.definition: The process of evaluating a string literal containing one or more placeholders, yielding a result in which the placeholders are replaced with their corresponding values

term.name: Merge Sort
term.definition: An efficient, general-purpose, comparison-based sorting algorithm

term.name: Mobile-first
term.definition: Designing an online experience for mobile before designing it for the desktop, web, or any other device

term.name: Mock
term.definition: A fake object that helps decide whether a test failed or passed by verifying whether an interaction with an object occurred

term.name: Permalink
term.definition: A URL that is intended to remain unchanged for many years into the future

term.name: Alpha
term.definition: An early stage sample with various API changes likely to come

term.name: Stub
term.definition: A simulate behavior of software components (or modules) that a module undergoing tests depends on

term.name: OAuth
term.definition: An open standard for token-based authentication and authorization on the Internet

term.name: Observable
term.definition: A variable watched for state changes to notify all registered observers and updated automatically

term.name: Assertion
term.definition: A statement that is expected to always be true at that point in the code

term.name: Exception
term.definition: An event which occurs during the execution of a program, that disrupts the normal flow of the program's instructions

term.name: Syntactically Awesome Style Sheets (SASS)
term.definition: A style sheet language allowing variables, nested rules, mixins, and more on top of CSS

term.name: Query String
term.definition: The part of a URL containing data that does not fit conveniently into a hierarchical path structure, generally key-value pairs

term.name: Quick Sort
term.definition: A sorting algorithm utilizing a divide-and-conquer strategy to sort data items by dividing a large array into two smaller arrays

term.name: Race Condition
term.definition: An undesirable situation that occurs when a device or system attempts to perform two or more operations at the same time,  the operations must be done in the proper sequence to be done correctly, which cannot be guaranteed

term.name: Regular Expression (RegEx)
term.definition: A sequence of characters that define a search pattern

term.name: RESTful API
term.definition: An architectural style that defines a set of constraints and properties based on HTTP CRUD actions

term.name: Sandbox
term.definition: A testing environment that isolates untested code changes and outright experimentation from the production environment or repository

term.name: Serialize / Deserialize
term.definition: The process of converting an object into a stream of bytes in order to store the object or transmit it to memory, a database, or a file

term.name: SQL Injection
term.definition: A code injection technique, used to attack data-driven applications, in which nefarious SQL statements are inserted into an entry field for execution

term.name: Structured Query Language (SQL)
term.definition: A standardized programming language used for managing and performing various operations on data in relational databases

term.name: User Experience (UX)
term.definition: The process of enhancing user satisfaction with a product by improving the usability, accessibility, and pleasure provided in the interaction with the product

term.name: Ruby
term.definition: A dynamic, reflective, object-oriented, general-purpose programming language influenced by Perl, Smalltalk, Eiffel, Ada, and Lisp

term.name: VueJS
term.definition: A progressive framework for building component-based user interfaces similar to Angular 1.x

term.name: Stack Overflow Error
term.definition: An undesirable condition in which a computer program tries to use more memory space than the call stack has available

term.name: Proxy
term.definition: A server acting as an intermediary between another computer or server

term.name: NodeJS
term.definition: An open-source, cross-platform JavaScript run-time environment that executes JavaScript code server-side

term.name: Database Management System (DBMS)
term.definition: A general-purpose software system for the definition, creation, querying, update, and administration of databases

term.name: Fat Arrow
term.definition: A shorthand JavaScript syntax for creating a function with the current context automatically bound

term.name: Beta
term.definition: A sample version of an upcoming release intended for testing in real world use

term.name: Release Candidate
term.definition: The final testing stage before public release of software or a project

term.name: Electron
term.definition: A desktop application wrapper for NodeJS applications

term.name: Hackathon
term.definition: An event dedicated to coding quickly, for fun or competition

term.name: Camel Case
term.definition: A naming convention with capitals for words inside words, e.g. PayPal, iPhone, MasterCard

term.name: False Positive
term.definition: An error which was expected to happen

term.name: Cypress
term.definition: An e2e testing framework comprised of Mocha, Chai, Electron

term.name: Mocha
term.definition: A NodeJS testing framework with a coffee-related name

term.name: Chai
term.definition: A NodeJS assertion framework with a tea name

term.name: Behavior Driven Development (BDD)
term.definition: A development strategy focusing on writing tests with readable sentences some times based on user stories

term.name: Meetup
term.definition: An event or gathering posted on a popular .com site

term.name: Model View Controller (MVC)
term.definition: An architectural pattern to divide an application into three interconnected parts to keep data, visual, and intermediary code separated

term.name: Callback
term.definition: A function to be called later, when an event or action completes, commonly created with Anonymous Functions

term.name: V8
term.definition: The JavaScript engine behind NodeJS

term.name: End 2 End Tests (e2e)
term.definition: A type of test to ensure functionality works from start to finish

term.name: Naming Convention
term.definition: A way to standardize naming variables, functions, classes, etc. in code

term.name: Web Graphics Library (WebGL)
term.definition: A JavaScript API for creating 2D and 3D graphics on the web

term.name: Browser API
term.definition: The core functionality built into a browsers rendering engine, such as Geolocation

term.name: Geolocation
term.definition: A JavaScript API to allow pinpointing a users location

term.name: Third-party
term.definition: A resource provided by another company or entity

term.name: Loop
term.definition: Control flow logic to allow running the same set of code a certain number of times

term.name: if / else if / else
term.definition: Control flow logic to allow running a code set when a condition matches

term.name: switch
term.definition: Control flow logic to allow matching a value with a specific case

term.name: while loop
term.definition: Control flow logic to allow looping while a condition is met

term.name: Minification
term.definition: The process of stripping white space and renaming variables to optimize code for file size

term.name: fetch
term.definition: A promise-based JavaScript API to handle AJAX requests

term.name: Access Token
term.definition: A string sent along with requests containing the security credentials for a login session to identify the user

term.name: Ad hoc
term.definition: Something happening or existing only for a particular purpose and not previously planned

term.name: Chrome Dev Tools
term.definition: A set of tools inside the browser consisting of the console, network, element inspector, and more

term.name: Clean Code
term.definition: Code that is easy to read and understand

term.name: Command-line Interface (CLI)
term.definition: The generic name for Terminal, Shell, Bash, etc.

term.name: Console
term.definition: A reference to the feedback tool used when logging or printing out items for debugging

term.name: Hotkey
term.definition: Another name for a keyboard shortcut with a little spice to it

term.name: Keep It Simple, Stupid (KISS)
term.definition: A principle stating that most systems work best if they are kept simple rather than made complicated

term.name: Hot Reload / Livereload
term.definition: A development tool to automatically inject new code into the browser as it is written

term.name: Integrated Development Environment (IDE)
term.definition: Software to ease the pain of writing code manually, usually geared towards a specific language or languages

term.name: Internet of Things (IoT)
term.definition: A reference to the ever-growing network of physical objects that feature an IP address for internet connectivity

term.name: Kitchen Sink
term.definition: A reference to a collection of demos lumped together as a showcase

term.name: S.O.L.I.D. Principles (SOLID)
term.definition: A mnemonic acronym for five design principles intended to make software designs more understandable, flexible and maintainable

term.name: Authentication
term.definition: A technique to confirm the user is who they say they are

term.name: Authorization
term.definition: A technique to check if a user has access to a specific resource

term.name: Stack
term.definition: A reference to the set of technologies and languages a company is using for their product or software

term.name: Scraping
term.definition: The act of programmatically parsing website code to grab data or information

term.name: HTTP Methods
term.definition: Types of requests we can make via HTTP, for example: GET, POST

term.name: Polyfill
term.definition: A fallback script or code to fill in holes of features missing from the browser

term.name: Concatenate
term.definition: To take one or more items and combine them into one

term.name: Coupled / Decoupled
term.definition: When two items are tightly reliant on each other

term.name: Object Relational Mapper (ORM)
term.definition: A library to help manage working with relational data

term.name: Override
term.definition: To take over a default or previously set value

term.name: Pair Programming
term.definition: The act of coding along with another individual, often referring to a driver and navigator scenario

term.name: Code Review
term.definition: The act of reviewing new or old code for quality purposes

term.name: Plain Ol' JavaScript Object (POJO)
term.definition: A common and simple data structure using Objects

term.name: Polymorphism
term.definition: A commonly used term to describe functions with many forms

term.name: Waterfall
term.definition: A project management process requiring completion of prior tasks before continuing on to the next (E.g. Design, Development, QA)

term.name: Split / Join
term.definition: Breaking apart a string or array, or the opposite of bringing them together

term.name: State
term.definition: A reference to the present values of data, settings, location, etc. of an app

term.name: Port
term.definition: A connection number used to offer multiple routes for one address on the internet or network

term.name: AngularJS
term.definition: A JavaScript framework for dynamic web apps built by the Google team

term.name: localStorage
term.definition: A browser storage API that allows saved data across browser sessions

term.name: sessionStorage
term.definition: A browser storage API that allows saved data for the current browser session

term.name: lodash
term.definition: A popular utility library used in JavaScript and Node applications

question.title: Tell me about a single-page application you've written or worked on
What are `let` and `const`?
question.answer: New to ES6, `let` and `const` allow us to set variables in lexical scope (or block scope)

question.title: What are some Native Array methods and what would you use them for?
question.answer: Some common Array methods are `.pop(), .push(), .shift(), .unshift()` for adding / removing data from an Array. For looping through data, you can use `.forEach()` or `.map(), .reduce()` to manipulate or accumulate data. Using `.filter(), .every(), .some()` can check if your data includes what you're looking for.

question.title: When would you use a `for` loop over `.forEach()`?
question.answer: A `.forEach()` loop will go through all items in the Array while a `for` loop can be cancelled early with a `break` statement.

question.title: What's the difference between encrypting and encoding a string?
question.answer: Encoding is changing the format of the data so that it can be transferred but does not require a key to reverse and isn't a secure method of transfer. Encryption requires a key to reverse and is used to transmit/store data securely.

question.title: When is a value `null` vs `undefined` vs undeclared?
question.answer: If we define a variable without a value it will be `undefined`. If we want to declare the value as "empty" we can set it to `null`. If we have never mentioned this variable before, it will be considered undeclared.

question.title: What are the three states of a Promise?
question.answer: Pending, we have initiated the code and are awaiting a response. Resolved, we have successfully returned a value. Failed, an error state when we did not receive what we expected.

question.title: What is the difference between Git and Github?
question.answer: Git is a Source Control system while Github is a hosting platform for Git repositories. Github has features like Forks, Pull Requests, and Issues.

question.title: Why would we want to host our files on a CDN?
question.answer: A CDN will provide performance benefits such as a global network, cookie-less domains, and hard caching rules to ensure quick delivery times.

question.title: What kind of files would count as Static Assets?
question.answer: Any files that do not need additional processing, such as HTML, CSS, JavaScript. Additionally, any kind of media files such as photos (jpg, png), videos (mov, mp4), documents (pdf, txt, md).

question.title: Explain the difference between Arguments and Parameters
question.answer: Parameters are defined with the function while Arguments are what is being passed to the function when it is invoked.

question.title: What would we use `.call()` and `.apply()` for?
question.answer: `.call()` and `.apply()` can be used to invoke a function or method with a specific context

question.title: What kind of requests can we make with AJAX?
question.answer: AJAX can (most commonly) make `GET, POST, PUT / PATCH, DELETE` requests. We can also make `OPTIONS, HEAD` requests if necessary.

question.title: What is CORS and why does it exist?
question.answer: CORS stands for Cross-origin Resource Sharing. It is implemented into browsers as a security feature to prevent one domain from requesting information to another domain without permission. We can set up our server to allow CORS requests if our data is intended to be publicly available.

question.title: What are the (dis)advantages to using CSS Grid over Flexbox?
question.answer: Flexbox is intended to distribute space among items in a container, even when their width is not know. CSS Grid allows us to create a row and column layout while keeping control of each items placement in the grid.

question.title: What are CSS floats best used for?
question.answer: CSS Floats are intended to pull an element out of the web page flow such as an image with text around it. Floats should not be used for layout now Flexbox and Grid are available.

question.title: What does "the page flow" refer to in HTML / CSS?
question.answer: When talking about "the page flow", we are indicating the order which elements get rendered to the page. Elements can be pulled out of the flow, which allows us to place things absolute, fixed, or as a float.

question.title: Tell me what Promises are and why would I use them?
question.answer: Promises provide a way for us to handle asynchronous code. We can use a Promise that will resolve when the result is returned, or reject if unsuccessful. We're commonly using Promises to deal with AJAX requests to / from a server.

question.title: What are CSS selectors?
Describe the specificity of CSS selectors
What is the difference between `.class1.class2` and `.class1 .class2`?
question.answer: `.class1.class2` is to select the same element with multiple class names while `.class1 .class2` is to select descendants.

question.title: How do you define a global variable inside of a function?
question.answer: We could leave off the `var` or set it as a property on `window`

question.title: What is the difference between `==` and `===`?
question.answer: A `===` is a strict check (including the type) while `==` will compare the values only. For example, `4 == '4'` is `true` while `4 === '4'` is `false`.

question.title: What is a closure?
question.answer: In JavaScript, a closure is a way to capture the outer scope inside of an inner scope.

question.title: How do CSS floats work?
question.answer: Floats allow you to pull an item out of the "flow" of the page, making nearby contents "float" around the item.

question.title: How do you center something in CSS?
question.answer: If it is text, you can use `text-align: center`. If it's an element, you can use Flexbox to fill space where you need.

question.title: How does event bubbling work?
question.answer: When you click on an element in the page, it will start at the deepest leaf, and move its way back up the DOM, triggering a click event on each parent.

question.title: Describe the DOM
question.answer: The DOM is our document structure turned into an interactive tree of nodes. We can traverse elements to find what we need, adjust properties on nodes, or listen / trigger events on elements.

question.title: What is the difference between a DOM Node and an Element?
question.answer: An element is an item on the page while a DOM Node is a reference to the element in the DOM.

question.title: What are some ways we can grab an element on the page?
question.answer: We could use `querySelector, querySelectorAll, getElementById, getElementsByClassName, getElements ByTagName`

question.title: What does DOM ready mean?
question.answer: DOM Ready means the DOM has been parsed and is ready to be interacted with

question.title: What can I do with Event Listeners?
question.answer: Event Listeners can listen for user events triggered on elements. Events are actions like click, mouseover, change, submit, etc.

question.title: How do you hide something using CSS?
question.answer: You can hide elements with `display: none`, `visibility: hidden`, or if you want to get tricky, positioning it outside of the viewport

question.title: What are some pros and cons of a Convention Over Configuration framework?
question.answer: Convention over configuration allows the developers to have a consistent codebase and set of rules to follow. However, if you are unfamiliar with it, there is a learning curve.

question.title: What are some ways to prevent Cross-site Scripting (XSS)?
question.answer: We can strip all HTML out of a users input upon save

question.title: What does an Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD) show us?
question.answer: An ERD is a conceptual and representational model of data used to represent the entities and the relationships between those entities

question.title: What kinds of information would we store in Environment Variables?
question.answer: Environment Variables commonly hold private data such as keys or secrets, as well as configuration settings for a specific environment

question.title: In terms of CSS, what is the difference between an Id and a class?
question.answer: An Id holds higher specificity and is intended to be used once per page. A class is reusable as many times as needed, and is capable of having multiple classes per element.

question.title: When would you use NoSQL over other database types?
question.answer: A NoSQL database is great for non-relational data such as a large JSON object or smaller sets of data when high-performance is preferred

question.title: Why would I want to use OAuth vs another Authentication implementation?
question.answer: OAuth will allow users to authenticate with existing accounts from various providers such as Facebook, Twitter, Github, etc. If our application needs Authentication and access to one of the third-party APIs, we could take care of both scenarios by implementing OAuth login.

question.title: What is a JavaScript API?
question.answer: A JavaScript API is one of the core features built into JavaScript, such as WebGL, Canvas, and most commonly the DOM API

question.title: What would I use a callback for?
question.answer: A callback can be used to run functionality once a specific event has occurred, or upon a task being completed

question.title: What is the difference between a Library and a Framework?
question.answer: The key difference between a library and a framework is “Inversion of Control”. When calling a method from a library, the developer is in control. With a framework, the control is inverted: the framework calls the developer’s code.

question.title: What is the difference between Authentication and Authorization?
question.answer: Authentication is confirming who you are, Authorization is confirming you have access

question.title: How can we check if a value is `NaN`?
What benefits do a front end framework provide?
question.answer: Front end frameworks will generally include handling DOM manipulations -- possibly through Virtual DOM -- breaking code into reusable Components, and some may include client-side routing and state management.

question.title: What are Props and State used for in ReactJS?
question.answer: Props allow us to pass our data down to child components and should also be treated as immutable. State allows us to track the current state of the component such as show / hide, expanded, or other data that might not be saved to a database but is still required in the interface.

question.title: What does it mean to pollute the global scope?
question.answer: Ideally, we want to keep variables out of the global scope if possible. This is so we don't accidentally override or inherit other code with the same variable names. Polluting the global scope would be adding variables to the global scope if it does not absolutely need to be there.

question.title: Tell me about yourself
Why do you want to work here?
What is your greatest weakness?
question.answer: chocolate

question.title: How do you handle stress and pressure?
What type of work environment do you prefer?
What challenges are you looking for in a position?
What are your career goals?
What is your greatest strength?
How would you describe the pace at which you work?
What motivates you?
If the people who know you were asked why you should be hired, what would they say?
Do you prefer to work independently or on a team?
How do you evaluate success?
What is the Virtual DOM?
question.answer: The Virtual DOM is a virtual representation of the DOM used to make changes before making real changes to the DOM. Making changes to the DOM is expensive, and virtual DOM will allow us to make the smallest amount of changes necessary for best performance.

question.title: What is your experience with testing applications?
question.answer: Sample: I have used mocha/chai to write unit tests and cypress to write end-to-end tests.  I can see the usefulness of testing in that it allows you to ensure that everything functions properly before you push to production.

question.title: What is middleware used for in Express?
question.answer: Middleware are the tools that Express utilizes to handle requests/responses before incoming/outgoing req/res are sent. Examples of common middleware are `cors` and `body-parser`.

question.title: When would we get a `NaN` value?
What are your pet peeves?
question.answer: [answer in a lighthearted manner]

question.title: If you knew your boss were 100% wrong about something, how would you handle it?
question.answer: [answer in your own personal preference, ideally describing how you could communicate without being hostile]

question.title: What major challenges and problems did you face at your last position and how did you handle them?
Is `fetch` a library or framework?
question.answer: `fetch` is actually a JavaScript API since it is built in to JavaScript. If it were third-party code, it would be a library.

question.title: What would you use `localStorage` for?
question.answer: `localStorage` is handy when you want to save user-specific preferences or non-private data between sessions

question.title: What are `req`, `res`, and `next` used for in ExpressJS?
question.answer: `req` is short for request which holds all information about the incoming request such as the headers, body, params, etc. `res` is short for response which is what we used to generate and send a response to the client with status codes, various response types, or headers. `next` is a callback for continuing on to the next middleware if we weren't handling the request with this middleware. For example, passing on to the error handler or adding information to the request then calling the next middleware.

question.title: What is Gitflow and how does it work?
question.answer: Gitflow allows a team to work asynchronously while trying to prevent merge conflicts and keep a deployable stable branch at any time. You have a master branch which is always ready to be published and in a working state. A develop branch which is where you create new branches for features, bug fixes, etc. A PR would be reviewed before merging into develop branch, then finally merged into master branch when ready for deployment.

question.title: When would you store state at component level vs application level?
question.answer: Typically, you want to store most of your state at application level when it affects more than one component (i.e. your user profile informs what data shows up when you interact with the app).  Conversely, storing state at a component level is useful when that change in state does not affect anything else in the entire app.

question.title: Explain the different type of data relationships (1:1, 1:many, many:many) and what you would use them for
question.answer:
one to one : a movie has ONE plot and a plot has ONE movie ; the relationship is strictly limited between two entities 

one to many : pets have ONE owner and an owner has MANY pets ( for the sake of the example ) ; the relationship has one entity with multiple relations that are still exclusive to the one entity

many to many : a book can have MANY authors and an author can have MANY books ; both entities can have multiple relationships relating to one another, foreign keys are used to help identify who belongs to who.

*Entity Relationship Diagrams are extremely helpful in organizing  this data*

question.title: What’s the difference between Enzyme and Jest?
question.answer: Enzyme is a testing framework for React while Jest is a test suite runner, not specific to React

question.title: What's the difference between a shallow and deep copy?
question.answer: A shallow copy will only make duplicates of the first level of items (such as an array), but any nested properties or values will still point to references. A deep copy will make duplicates of any level of nesting.

question.title: How would you make a copy of an object?
question.answer: In JavaScript you could use the ES6 spread operator to copy values to a new object. There are also some Object methods such as `.assign()`.

question.title: What work are you most proud of?
question.answer: [Showcase work fitting your particular skillset, whether that is front end, UI, responsive, etc.]

question.title: Do you take work home with you?
question.answer: [provide an honest answer and the reason why you do or don't. this is not a qualifying question, but a preference.]

question.title: What are your salary expectations?
question.answer: [provide a range of your ideal salary to allow for negotiation based on job criteria. some things to think about are work load, commute / transportation, skillset required, frequency of raises / performance reviews, career path]

question.title: What is a pure function?
question.answer: A function given the same input, will always return the same output, producing no side-effects

question.title: What are the Primitive Data Types in JavaScript?
question.answer: String, Number, Boolean, null, undefined and new to ES6, Symbol.

question.title: What is a Polyfill used for?
question.answer: A polyfill is used to act as a fallback when a core API feature is not available in the browser, such as WebGL, Canvas, etc.

question.title: When would you use `localStorage` vs `sessionStorage`?
question.answer: `localStorage` can save data across browser sessions while `sessionStorage` will only last for the current session. If you do not want the data to last for more than a session, you would prefer `sessionStorage`.

question.title: What is a Proxy useful for?
What is a Race Condition and what could cause one?
